Author: Gateway#3763

Author: Gateway#3763

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <mavenL> Staking reward right now create new t-address

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <jimboscott> But, the staking reward also involved a Z address as well...

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <jimboscott> Never seen that before

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <jimboscott> I cannot upgrade right now - OK to leave alone for a few hours?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <jimboscott> Why would a normally staked block get a Z address involved?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <miketout> A few answers @jimboscott @John Westbrook @grewalsatinder  @dukeleto :
1. We have identified a few small issues while running under Sapling on mainnet. None of them are serious, and we will address all in the next few days. The relevant one here is that currently all stakes are being delegated to a new address that would have been the address when you are mining. Until the next update, POS does not respect -pubkey and will payout to new addresses as if mining without pubkey
2. The code base should allow Equihash + VerusPOS after integration. Someone would have to do some work and understand the new chain power rules to add other POW algorithms, but VerusPOS doesn't really know or care what the specific POW algorithm is.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <John Westbrook> Thanks for the update @miketout, really enjoying the incredible performance improvements and great that everything has transitioned so smoothly, I know that's not by accident, very deliberately outstanding and devoted dev work by you and the other devs here.  Kudos.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <jimboscott> @miketout What was really different about the block I saw come in was the fact that it had a Z address as part of the chain of transactions.  I have never seen that before.  There were 4 wallet entries.  From the first to last, it was a known T address IN of 300, a Z address in of 0, a T address OUT of 300, then the block reward to a new T address.  All at the same block height.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <CryptoAlex> @jimboscott Happened to me today. AFAIK, StakeGuard works is by spending the cheater coins when they mature to your cheat catch S-address, so my conclusion is that the immature coins that go to a T-address can't be the result of cheat catch and are just a regular stake. I have no idea why the Z-transaction is there, though

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> @jimboscott right. the issue is that the OP_RETURN of the stake transaction is showing up as a 0 amount transaction and because Agama doesn't know the destination (there is none), it assumes unknown Z. for the point release, I am adding information to the transactions that indicate whether they are stake transactions, mined coinbases, or minted coinbases. getting this information took more API calls before than it will after this change. Verus Agama will use this to collapse all the stake ins and outs into one, obvious "stake" transaction that shows the amount. We also expect to differentiate between mined and minted.

Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> @Matterbridge honestly I'd say a threadripper 1950x or 2950x for price/performance and power use.
